BE11:24am

AAPL reported F4Q18 revenue/EPS of $62.9B/$2.91, beating consensus of $61.5B/$2.78E and our estimates of $60.6B/$2.73E. iPhone ASP grew 28% Y/Y, more than offsetting 4% iPhone unit decline and driving overall sales up 20% Y/Y. While Greater China delivered a respectable 16% Y/Y sales growth, all other regions grew faster. Service revenues were up organically 27% Y/Y and wearables were up 50% Y/Y. Total paid subscriptions grew another 30M Q/Q to 330M, based on 30,000 thirdparty subscription apps and Apple's in-house offerings such as iCloud. Our mid-term theses remain unchanged; we are concerned about gradual high-end share gain from Android competitors. Longer term, we expect IoT and alternative interface services (voice) to erode Apple's smartphone-centric platform advantage.

irish hedge fund guy I have a Nokia 6 for €200 and it works fine. Also just put google play on my Kindle Fire, €100 for the 10" in black Friday! IPAD and Iphone very expensive for nice user experience!

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We support management's decision to drive analyst attention away from product unit sales and to subscription, active installed base, and engagement. This is a reasonable step in the late adoption cycle of smartphones; however, it does expose Apple to more formidable competitors outside of the hardware business.

Excel Developer @tonyb: mutual abuse, we used to call them rabble on the left ROTL.

Baru Anything on Faraday (no-)Future?
BE11:25am

Apple reported strong FQ4 revenue, but missed on FQ1 guidance due to weakness in EMs and adverse currency movements. The company said they did not see weak consumer demand in China in FQ4 but we believe FQ1 guidance may still assume some potential for weaker demand there given ongoing macro uncertainty. As we had expected heading into the print, ASPs were strong (7.5% beat) and we are taking up our ASP numbers for FY19, but reducing our iPhone units estimate. Apple also announced that they will stop providing unit data beginning next quarter though they will begin providing margins for both services and product. We also believe the company is likely to continue to provide segment level active installed base numbers irregularly. Overall, our FY19 EPS declines by 5.5% and we are taking down our 12-month PT to $222 from $240 based on a 16x P/E multiple and our lower earnings forecast. Remain Neutral.

BE11:28am

Investors were surprised that the company will no longer provide iPhone, iPad, and Mac unit data and some investors will view this as a negative that the company is trying to hide information that in the past was so important to assess the company’s strength. While we agree ASPs do indeed impact reported revenues a lot, we know investors keenly monitor units as a key performance indicator. To us, most importantly is the Apple installed base of users growing or not and with unit data the answer to this question will only potentially be addressed qualitatively during future earnings calls. In a few quarters if Apple continues to show year over year sales and EPS growth and strong cash flow generation while giving qualitative information about its uses and sales we believe investors may look back at this financial disclosure change and view it as a sub optimal communication situation which may have been better communicated more in advance and less confusing.

FATDAZ @Irish yes indeed bought mine from John lewis as well so no arguments if no good etc
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Ivestors were hoping for gross margin improvement in December given the lower DRAM and NAND memory costs. Apple stated a help of 30bps from lower memory costs but FX will be a 90bps headwind and the gap is filled by higher volumes thereby resulting in flattish total company gross margins. We see upside to this as memory declines have been falling faster than expected. This negative may resolve itself when the company reports again in 3 months should memory pricing continue to decline.

irish hedge fund guy $120bn for IBM and $33bn for Red Hat.. mind you 33x cash flow for RHT
BE11:29am

Finally on a good note the public perception and reviews of Apple’s newest Mac and iPad are coming in very favorable as these products were just announced 2 days ago and available in ample time for Christmas holiday season. We see upside to Apple’s sales outlook of $89-93B versus consensus of $92.9B

BE11:29am

For these three reasons we believe Apple is leaving investors speechless with 2 big negatives (no more iPhone units and lack of gross margin improvement) and 1 big positive (great new Mac and iPad launches) as we head into the Christmas holiday. We see this stock pull back as a good opportunity to buy the stock and believe Apple may more aggressively use its stock buy back and we maintain our Buy rating and lower our target price to $240 from $265.

1) President Xi and President Trump talked about potentially meeting at the G2 meeting. President Trump said that discussions were “moving along nicely”; 2) Bloomberg reported that President Trump wants to reach an agreement on trade with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit and has asked key US officials to start drafting potential terms. This was followed by the White House’s economic advisor commenting that US-China might be able to break the logjam during the Nov 30-Dec 1 summit. Markets are taking this well - Chinese indices are up 2.5-3.5% and commodities (base metals) are also outperforming materially - copper is up c. 2.5% (at the time of writing).

BE11:44am

We have seen mixed messages arise from the Trump administration at pivotal moments in the trade dispute
with China, and today’s events offered no hint of a shift in strategy. On one hand, President Trump spoke positively of his contacts with President Xi of China, signaling good progress in talks as the two leaders prepare to meet and discuss trade issues on the sidelines of the G20 summit late November. The messaging could be driven by a desire to ease investor fears and generate positive headlines heading into next week’s midterm elections. A good-faith demonstration of outreach after a lengthy break in official negotiations could also serve to give the Administration political cover if talks at the G20 do not produce a demonstrable win. On the other hand, the DOJ announced a task force designed to identify and prosecute China’s intellectual property violations and threats to high-tech industries, a move that could be met with a tit-for-tat response from Beijing as a face-to-face meeting looms.

We perform a deep dive into the payment processing landscape within German e-commerce. Our analysis raises concerns around Wirecard's competitive positioning and the sustainability of growth that the market is pricing into its shares. Ingenico appears to be better placed than Wirecard within the German e-com payment processing environment.

Bluesky21 Starbucks and Kraft both had eventful earnings

5 merchants out of the top 100, accounting for 1.2% of German e-com volume appear to use Wirecard as their processor

BE11:49am

Ingenico, for comparison, has 4% of volume and 10 merchants.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Yet Wirecard “is perceived by some investors we speak to as a key payment processing player in the German e-commerce landscape."

BE11:51am

Largely because its own numbers suggest a much, much greater share of the pie. What gives?

BE11:52am

Do transaction volumes bundle in added services, like risk management or whatever? Maybe. But based on competitor rates those don't support Wirecard-level margins.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

So maybe the transaction numbers include in-store transactions done on Wirecard Bank cards, where the company earns an interchange fee?

BE11:53am

Again, difficult to see why that'd be high margin.

BE11:53am

Reconciling German transaction volumes at Wirecard and its competitors with total e-com volumes in Germany raises concerns around (1) quality of Wirecard's product offering, (2) sustainability of Wirecard's pricing/volume growth and (3) level of acquiring risk Wirecard may be taking on. These factors reduce our confidence in the sustainability of growth that the market is pricing in. Valuation has re-rated strongly over the last 12 months (charts 6-9) driven by (1) increasing investor optimism around the sector, (2) the market pricing in stronger growth over longer time horizons and (3) optimism around recently announced payment partnership with Credit Agricole.

BE12:02pm

Brexit talks are moving to the crunch point. Our
view remains that the currency market is underpricing the risk of a disorderly outcome, even if this is not our base case, and particularly with respect to the parliamentary vote. In that respect, we remain tactically short the pound, although acknowledge that the price action is highly volatile, and agreement between the UK and EU27 could result in a short-term rally.
Progress could be announced as soon as next week, when the UK is to formally respond to the latest EU27 proposals on the UK-wide backstop. If this is the case, a late November summit between the UK and EU27 is possible, and a parliamentary vote would follow shortly thereafter (perhaps in the week of 26th November). If agreement does not crystallise next week, then a mid-December deal (and parliamentary vote in the week 17th December) would be our base case.

BE12:05pm

We expect a favourable decision for INDV on the PI appeal: The timing for the decision on the ongoing PI appeal is unclear although we expect an expedited appeal decision to be made within 90 days of the start of the briefing on 4 October, which implies a decision should be made in 4Q. In our last report (HERE) we highlighted the downside risk of a PI loss; however, while we are not legal experts, we continue to expect a favourable outcome for INDV given:
■ the reason why DRRD had success in the '514 patent litigation was due to the interpretation of the drying process outlined in the '514 patent. The '305 patent covers similar IP to the '514 although the district court ruled that the '305 patent did not imply a drying limitation in its claims;
■ the initial court ruling on the PI determined that it is likely that DRRD infringes the '305 patent; a reversal on the PI would suggest such a significant difference in opinion between the court rulings that we expect it is unlikely. i.e. it would need to rule that DRRD clearly doesn't infringe on the PI.
